# Topic 2: Introduction to Alternative Investments

## SubTopic 2.6: Financial Economics Foundations

### Informational Market Efficiency

Informational market efficiency refers to the extent to which asset prices reflect available information.

An informationally efficient market is a market in which assets are traded at prices that equal their values based on all available information. 

The concept of informational market efficiency is referred to as efficient market theory or efficient market hypothesis.

All financial markets display some informational market efficiency, but no financial market is perfectly efficient.

- Further Definitions of Informational Market Efficiency

Informationally efficient markets are described as markets in which net present values (NPVs) of all investment decisions are zero.

Informationally efficient markets are described as markets in which investors are unable to use information to consistently earn superior risk‚Äêadjusted returns.

Investors bearing higher risk should earn consistently higher returns, and any investor bearing risk might occasionally earn high returns.

However, in informationally efficient market, investors cannot earn higher expected returns without bearing additional risk.
